name: Musee d'Orsay

hours.notes: Last admission at 5pm (9pm on Thursdays). Galleries close at 5:30pm (9:15pm on Thursdays). Late night opening Thursdays until 9:45pm.

admission.notes: Online purchase 16 EUR, on-site 14 EUR. Free for under 18s and EU residents under 26. Night rate 12 EUR online, 10 EUR on-site. First Sunday of month is free.

crowdData.seasonalNotes: Much less crowded than the Louvre. Thursday evenings are particularly good. First Sunday of month is free but crowded.
crowdData.recommendedDuration: 2-3 hours for highlights, 4 hours for thorough visit

tips: Thursday evening is the best time to visit with extended hours until 9:45pm
The building itself is a converted railway station. Worth admiring the architecture
Start on the top floor with the Impressionists to beat the crowds
The cafe on the 5th floor has a terrace with views of Paris
Free first Sunday of the month but expect longer queues
Combined tickets available with the Rodin Museum and Orangerie

amenities.nearbyParking: Underground parking nearby on Rue de Solferino

mustSee.name: Starry Night Over the Rhone
mustSee.note: One of Van Gogh's famous night scenes

mustSee.name: Luncheon on the Grass
mustSee.note: Controversial painting that shocked Paris in 1863

mustSee.name: Dance at Moulin de la Galette

faqs.question: What are the most famous paintings at the Musée d'Orsay?
faqs.answer:
The Musée d'Orsay houses the world's largest collection of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist masterpieces. Among the most celebrated works are Édouard Manet's Le Déjeuner sur l'herbe and Olympia, both revolutionary paintings that challenged academic conventions. Pierre-Auguste Renoir's Dance at Le Moulin de la Galette captures the vibrant energy of Parisian nightlife.

The museum also features Vincent van Gogh's Starry Night Over the Rhone and several of his famous self-portraits. Cézanne's The Card Players is considered one of the most important Post-Impressionist works.

Other highlights include Jean-François Millet's L'Angélus, Gustave Courbet's monumental A Burial at Ornans, and James McNeill Whistler's iconic Arrangement in Grey and Black (Whistler's Mother). For sculpture, Edgar Degas' Little Dancer of Fourteen Years remains one of the museum's most beloved works.

faqs.question: What is the history of the Musée d'Orsay?
faqs.answer:
The Musée d'Orsay occupies the former Gare d'Orsay, a railway station designed by architect Victor Laloux in the Beaux-Arts style. The station opened on May 28, 1900, just in time for the Paris World's Fair. It was the first electrified urban terminal station in the world and also contained a 370-room hotel.

The station served trains running to southwest France until 1939, when longer train cars made the platforms too short. After closing to long-distance traffic, the building served various purposes: a reception center for repatriated prisoners after WWII, and a backdrop for films by Orson Welles and Bernardo Bertolucci.

President Valéry Giscard d'Estaing announced the museum project in 1978. Italian architect Gae Aulenti designed the interior galleries, transforming the industrial space into an art museum. The Musée d'Orsay officially opened in December 1986 under President François Mitterrand. It was the first time an industrial building had been converted into a major museum.

faqs.question: How long does it take to see the Musée d'Orsay?
faqs.answer:
Most visitors should plan for 2 to 4 hours at the Musée d'Orsay. If you want to see the highlights without feeling rushed, allocate at least 2 hours. Art enthusiasts who want to explore the collection more thoroughly often spend 5 to 6 hours. The museum displays roughly 3,000 works at any given time across multiple floors.

If you're short on time or primarily interested in the Impressionists, you can focus on the fifth floor galleries, where the core collection of Monet, Renoir, Degas, and other Impressionist masters is displayed. A quick tour of just this floor takes about 2 hours.

The museum is open from 9:30 AM to 6:00 PM most days, with extended hours until 9:45 PM on Thursdays. To avoid crowds, visit on Wednesday or Friday mornings, or take advantage of Thursday evening hours.

faqs.question: How much do tickets cost for the Musée d'Orsay?
faqs.answer:
Standard admission to the Musée d'Orsay costs €16. This ticket includes access to both the permanent collections and any temporary exhibitions. For Thursday evening visits after 6:00 PM, a reduced rate of €12 applies.

Free admission is available for visitors under 18 years old, EU and European Economic Area residents aged 18 to 25, visitors with disabilities and one accompanying person, and everyone on the first Sunday of each month.

The museum strongly recommends buying tickets online in advance. Without a pre-purchased ticket, expect wait times of around 50 minutes at the main entrance during busy periods. Tuesday tends to be the most crowded day since the Louvre is closed.

faqs.question: What floor are the Impressionists on at the Musée d'Orsay?
faqs.answer:
The famous Impressionist collection is located on the fifth floor of the Musée d'Orsay. This floor houses masterpieces by Claude Monet, Édouard Manet, Pierre-Auguste Renoir, Edgar Degas, Paul Cézanne, Camille Pissarro, and Alfred Sisley. Post-Impressionist galleries featuring Van Gogh and Toulouse-Lautrec are also on this level.

Most visitors head directly to the fifth floor via escalators at the far end of the main atrium. The fifth floor also features the Café Campana, one of Paris's most stylish museum cafes, located adjacent to the Impressionist galleries.

The ground floor features sculptures and earlier 19th-century paintings, while the middle levels contain decorative arts and additional galleries.

faqs.question: Can you take photos at the Musée d'Orsay?
faqs.answer:
Yes, photography is allowed at the Musée d'Orsay. The museum lifted its controversial photo ban in 2015. You can now photograph and video record works in the permanent collection for personal, non-commercial use.

There are a few rules to follow. Flash photography is prohibited to protect the artworks. Tripods, selfie sticks, and lighting equipment are not allowed in the galleries and must be left in the cloakroom. Some works, particularly in temporary exhibitions, may have individual photo restrictions.

Professional or commercial filming and photography requires authorization from the museum. For personal use, you're free to capture the famous clock, the soaring glass-roofed nave, and the masterpieces throughout the collection.

descriptionHtml:
The Musée d'Orsay houses the world's greatest collection of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist art. Monet's water lilies, Van Gogh's Starry Night Over the Rhône, Manet's Olympia, Renoir's Bal du moulin de la Galette. These paintings changed art history, and they're all here under one spectacular roof.

That roof belongs to a former railway station. The Gare d'Orsay opened in 1900 for the World's Fair, its iron-and-glass architecture considered too beautiful for trains. Threatened with demolition in the 1970s, it was saved and transformed into a museum in 1986. The soaring nave now showcases sculptures where trains once ran. The original station clocks still mark time. It's one of the world's great adaptive reuse projects, and one of Paris's most atmospheric museum experiences.
historicalContext: The Gare d'Orsay railway station opened in 1900 to serve southwestern France and coincide with the World's Fair. Architect Victor Laloux designed it with a grand hotel facade hiding the iron-and-glass train shed behind Beaux-Arts stone. By 1939, electrified trains made the platforms too short, and the station closed to mainline traffic. The building served various purposes: a mail center during WWII, a filming location for Orson Welles' The Trial, and a theater venue. President Valéry Giscard d'Estaing saved it from demolition in 1977, commissioning its conversion to a museum dedicated to art from 1848-1914, bridging the gap between the Louvre and the Centre Pompidou. The Musée d'Orsay opened on December 1, 1986.
whyVisit: World's largest collection of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist masterpieces
Van Gogh, Monet, Renoir, Degas, Cézanne under one roof
The giant station clock with views across the Seine
Shorter crowds than the Louvre, more focused collection
Perfect complement to a Louvre visit (different eras)
